awd_titl_txt: Conference: Broadening Participation (BPart) and NSF Network Breakfast Events at ASME-IDETC-CIE 2023; Boston, Massachusetts; 20-23 August 2023
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will broaden the participation of students and those from underrepresented groups and enhance the exchange of ideas during the 2023 ASME International Design Engineering Technical Conferences & Computers and Information in Engineering Conference (IDETC-CIE 2023). IDETC-CIE is the second largest conference organized annually by the American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME) and typically brings 500-1000 participants from academia, industry, national laboratories, funding agencies, and policymaking bodies. The conference enables collaboration, knowledge sharing, and skill development across all engineering disciplines, while promoting the vital role of engineers in society. The objective of broadening participation in this conference will be fulfilled by adding a series of NSF-sponsored events to the conference program that will actively bring together and engage students and underrepresented groups in a dedicated creative thinking environment. These events will be supplemented by a networking breakfast, in which attendees will come together with NSF program officers to discuss topics related to engineering faculty careers, industry jobs for students, increasing diversity, promoting industry-academia partnerships, enhanced pedagogy, and promoting emerging areas of research in science and engineering, among other topics. The proposed series of events will open new doors of research and creativity for students, faculty, and industry participants.

The first objective of this award is to support the mission of the 2023 ASME International Design Engineering Technical Conferences & Computers and Information in Engineering Conference (ASME-IDETC-CIE 2023) for broadening participation of underrepresented groups by offering a kick-off dinner event for 30 participants and a student networking event for 150 students. These two events will bring students and other attendees from diverse backgrounds together to brainstorm research ideas in a conducive and inclusive environment. This cross-fertilization of ideas will have the potential to inspire new interdisciplinary research directions and to provide potential breakthroughs for current barriers in the participants’ research. The second objective of this award is to facilitate the collaboration and professional development of 250 participants through a networking breakfast at this conference. This breakfast event will complement the kick-off dinner and student networking events, which will be held early in the conference, to help students and underrepresented participants feel more comfortable intermingling and subsequently learning and sharing ideas throughout the conference.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF-funded project, “Broadening Participation (BPart) and NSF Network Breakfast Events at ASME-IDETC-CIE 2023,” aimed to foster diversity and professional networking in the engineering community by organizing key events at the ASME International Design Engineering Technical Conferences & Computers and Information in Engineering Conference (IDETC-CIE), held in Boston, Massachusetts, from August 20-23, 2023.

Intellectual Merit:

The project’s intellectual merit centered on facilitating meaningful exchanges between students, early-career researchers, and seasoned professionals from academia, industry, and government. The NSF Network Breakfast, featuring multiple round-table discussions, covered topics such as work-life balance, digital engineering, diversity and inclusion (DEIA), collaboration strategies, and emerging research areas in engineering. These discussions allowed attendees to gain insights into the latest trends and challenges in mechanical engineering and related fields, fostering knowledge exchange and opening avenues for future collaborations.

Additionally, the project supported the Broadening Participation (BPart) initiative, which provided mentorship and financial support to students and researchers from underrepresented groups in engineering. The initiative helped participants build professional networks, receive career guidance, and engage with the broader research community, contributing to a more diverse and inclusive engineering field.

Broader Impacts:

This project made significant contributions to broadening participation and inclusion in the engineering community. The BPart initiative facilitated the participation of individuals from historically underrepresented groups, including women, racial minorities, and individuals with disabilities, ensuring they had access to the same professional opportunities and networks as their peers. The project’s focus on diversity and inclusion aligns closely with NSF’s mission to promote equitable access to scientific and professional opportunities.

Furthermore, the NSF-funded events catalyzed broader industry involvement. For instance, MathWorks, initially attracted by the networking breakfast, not only sponsored the conference for the first time but also provided a training workshop and committed to future sponsorship. This involvement from industry leaders has the potential to shape future conferences and further bridge the gap between academia and industry.

The round-table discussions, which addressed topics such as balancing career and personal life, collaboration between academia and industry, and pathways for career advancement, also contributed to participants' professional growth. These events encouraged the exchange of ideas that will likely influence future professional practices, helping to create a more inclusive and collaborative engineering community.

In summary, this project supported crucial events that promoted diversity, fostered networking and mentorship, and facilitated collaborations between academia, industry, and government. The outcomes of these efforts have the potential to drive long-term change, improving diversity and inclusion in the engineering field while enhancing the professional development of attendees.
